prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: As indicated, art. 2089 C.C.Q. does not distinguish between non-competiton and non-solicitation clauses. It has been argued before the Superior Court that a non-solicitation clause should have a geographical limitation. After noting that there was no such limitation and, more particularly, no list of clients attached to the employment contract, the court declared the clause in question abusive, null and void.[1]
A recent judgment considered the possibility for an employer to draft a clause that, in essence, could be reviewed by a tribunal in case of litigation. The clause reads as follows:

“Territory” means each Province of Canada or, if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such area to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the area of the Province of Ontario, Québec and each Province of Canada West of Ontario or, if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such area to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the area of the Province of Québec and Ontario or, if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such area to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the area of the Province of Québec or, if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such area to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the area within a radius of fifty miles of Montreal, Québec;

“Time Period” means the period of four years form the Date of Termination or, if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such period to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the period of three years from the Date of Termination, or if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such period to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the period of two years from the Date of Termination, or if a court of competent jurisdiction determines such period to be unreasonable for the purposes of paragraph 16, the period of one year form the Date of Termination;

However, this goes against the normal principle that the courts do not revise or draft non-competition covenants, but only decide on their validity. The Superior Court has also decided that such a clause was not valid because, inter alia, it created a state of uncertainty for the employee until a tribunal could decide on its validity.[2]
Finally, with the reform of the C.C.Q., arts. 1379 and 1437 read as follows:
1379. A contract of adhesion is a contract in which the essential stipulations were imposed or drawn up by one of the parties, on his behalf or upon his instructions, and were not negotiable.
Any contract that is not a contract of adhesion is a contract by mutual agreement.
1437. An abusive clause in a consumer contract or contract of adhesion is null, or the obligation arising from it may be reduced.

An abusive clause is a clause which is excessively and unreasonably detrimental to the consumer or the adhering party and is therefore not in good faith; in particular, a clause which so departs from the fundamental obligations arising from the rules normally governing the contract that it changes the nature of the contract is an abusive clause.

Some Québec courts have seriously considered the proposition that a restrictive covenant, when included in an employment contract that could also constitute an adhesion contract, may properly be reduced in scope.[3] However, in each such case the relevant clauses were not considered excessive in the circumstances. This jurisprudential tendency seems to contravene the principle, elaborated by the Supreme Court of Canada, that a tribunal does not have jurisdiction to rewrite an unreasonable clause where the parties have clearly not empowered the tribunal to do so.
Emballages Dawson v. Béland Inc., [1994] R.J.Q. 1613 (S.C.).
Graphiques Matrox Inc. v. nVidia Corp., [2001] Q.J. No. 3344 (S.C.).
2757-5331 Québec Inc. vs. 2865-8169 Québec Inc., [2003] Q.J. No. 4516 (S.C.) and Services Investors Ltée vs. Hudson, [1998] A.Q. No. 1414 (S.C.).
